abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Small
            Industries Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory. The
            project achieved some of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was negligible, sustainability is
            uncertain at this time, and the performance of both the Bank
            and Borrower was less than satisfactory. Several lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, an efficient and
            effective Apex Institution is crucial to the success of this
            type of project, particularly during the period of
            institutional development and sector strengthening. Second,
            IDA needs to define clear performance standards and
            sanctions in case of non-performance for participating
            financial intermediaries. Third, IDA should not transfer
            responsibilities to its Resident Missions before preparation
            and clear definition of tasks are complete. Fourth, IDA
            should take into account that financial markets and policies
            may change, particularly when it is pressing for financial
            reforms. Fifth, IDA should devote more attention and staff
            resources to the supervision of technical assistance. Sixth,
            technical support to less developed regions can only be
            effective when adequate infrastructure and technically
            qualified personnel are in place. Lastly, IDA should take a
            more proactive role in administrating its co-financing funds.
